description:
But we begin the programme in Nepal, still struggling to cope with the aftermath of the earthquake that killed more than seven and a half thousand people. Attention is now focused squarely on the survivors, and there's a warning that unless immediate action is taken, disease could become the next killer. Without shelter, many people are living in the open with no basic sanitation. And yet, the Nepalese authorities say that ten days on, they are getting on top of the relief effort. So what is the situation in Nepal? The BBC's Anu Anand reports.

"I'm walking down the main street in Chautara town. Every time you come through this narrow thoroughfare, you're just shocked all over again at the level of destruction. I'm standing next to the remains of an entire house. It's completely come down into a pile of, just, utter devastation. And just to give you an idea, just here, right under my feet is a yellow motorcycle with a red number plate, and the front half of it is buried under the roof of the house."
